Award.AwardTitle: SBIR Phase I: Soft Foam Polyurethanes from Algae Oil
Award.AbstractNarration:
The broader impact/commercial potential of this Small Business Innovation Research (SBIR) project is to create sustainable and biodegradable polyurethane products made from algae oils. Algae-based polymer precursors will be developed and used to produce finished polyurethane product with the desired physical characteristics. Development of polyurethane shoe soles will be targeted, including polyurethane flip-flops, as these are products where consumers are increasingly demanding the incorporation of sustainable materials and where the consumer is willing to pay the small extra cost associated with incorporating renewable materials. Developing algae polymers and high value products made from these will allow us to develop a novel monomer toolbox based on these bio-materials and to create new polymers with physical properties equal or superior to petroleum based polymers. These algae based polymers also provide cleaner, smarter products- pollution prevention at the molecular level. The development of environmentally sustainable and biodegradable products will reduce waste, prevent costly end-of-life remediation, lead to safer products and save energy and water resources. The development of these algae based polymer products will enable renewable materials to supplant petroleum-based materials while maintaining the performance characteristics of polyurethane products that consumers have come to appreciate.

This SBIR Phase I project proposes to develop sustainable monomers from bio-based algae feedstocks that will be used to create finished polyurethane soft foams that have the appropriate properties for shoe soles. It incorporates the preparation of algae-based polyols from multiple algae oil sources, going from bench to production scale, followed by formulation of these monomers into materials that meet the demands of a discerning eco-conscious consumer. The developed algae polyols will not be formulaic direct drop-in replacements for the corresponding petroleum sourced materials' careful formulation will be required to generate polyurethanes with the desired final product properties, and that are also compatible with current manufacturing techniques. Formulation and process compatibility are key steps, as industrial users are not looking to significantly modify manufacturing processes to incorporate new starting materials. Lastly, physical evaluation of the resulting polyurethanes will be done by comparing the performance metrics between bio and petroleum-based polyurethanes typically used by end users in sportswear and automotives. Using polyols derived from multiple algal strains, a polyurethane formulation for soft foams will be developed to demonstrate our ability to integrate product development and manufacturing, from sustainable feedstock and green chemistry through commercial application.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Algenesis has completed our NSF SBIR Phase I project: Soft Foam Polyurethanes from Algae Oil. We began this project based on the observations that consumers were demanding environmentally friendly and sustainably sourced polyurethane products, and that there was an opportunity to meet this demand, because the large chemical suppliers we unable or unwilling to develop bio-based polyurethanes that meet specification for the shoe industry. Polyurethanes are used in many products worldwide, including soft polyurethanes foams like those found shoe midsoles, or even flip flops.  All polyurethanes used today have two major environmental problems, they are derived from petroleum, a finite and energy-intensive resource, and second, they are not biodegradable, meaning that polyurethane products made today will last in the environment for hundreds of years. To address this issue, many companies have elected to use recycled materials in their products, and although a great improvement over virgin plastics, only a few percent of the recyclable plastics are recycled today, and polyurethanes, especially the thermoset polyurethanes used in shoe midsole are not recycled at all.  Rather than focus on recyclable polymers, Algenesis, is focused on developing renewable and sustainable bio-based polyurethanes that biodegrade at the end of life, so that we never accumulate plastic waste, no matter how it is disposed.

 

Our Phase I SBIR was aimed at developing both the correct monomer chemistry as well as the right polymer formulations, so that the end result was soft polyurethane foams that could meet commercial specification. As we developed these polyurethanes we also maintained a chemistry that allowed for biodegradation of the resulting foams at the end of the useful life of the product. For monomer chemistry during this Phase I SBIR, we focused on developing a suite of polyurethane monomers known as polyols. Using a variety of chemical transformations we developed polyols from algae oils and other biological molecules that gave us linear polyol molecules of various length and molecular configurations. We then used these polyols with different isocyanates, surfactants, catalysts and blowing agents to formulate a variety of soft polyurethanes foams.  To develop renewable soft polyurethane foams with the right physical properties, we worked closely with two shoe industry leaders to develop foams suitable for both athletic shoe midsoles and for flip flop footbeds. As we developed these new formulations of soft foam polyurethanes, we sent these to our commercial collaborators for rigorous physical testing. Based upon feedback from these partners, we made additional foams and completed additional rounds of testing and refinement, eventually arriving at suitable foams for both athletic shoe midsoles and flip flops footbeds.


At the end of Phase I we have met or exceeded almost all the metrics for both industry standard flip flop footbeds and outsoles, and we have met or exceeded most of the metrics for industry standard athletic midsoles. In the areas where we have not met the metrics, we have made consistent improvements. We have also explored many types of algal and other non-food-based polyols and found a scalable source of algae oil, significantly cutting our raw material cost.

 

 


Last Modified: 03/15/2019
Modified by: Marissa A Tessman

Images (1 of )
  • Our progression of flip flop prototypes. Starting from the top left and ending at the bottom right, you can see our improvements as we discovered more about our material.
    Marissa Tessman
    Copyrighted
    Marissa A Tessman
    A history of Algenesis renewable flip flop prototypes
  • Sustainable, biodegradable flip flops on a beach in the Maldives. Even the Maldives, known as one of the most isolated island chains in the world, has trash washing up on its beaches. Algenesis flip flops, on the other hand, will leave no trace!
    Stephen Mayfield
    Copyrighted
    Marissa A Tessman
    Algenesis flip flops in the Maldives
